splashscreen.title: A Racing Glacier
splashscreen.subtitle: Jakobshavn, Greenland
splashscreen.altText: A Racing Glacier in Jakobshavn, Greenland

slides.text: Greenland loses more ice through the Jakobshavn Glacier than from anywhere else on this huge ice sheet. Jakobshavn – one of the fastest moving glaciers in the world – travels up to 40 metres per day.

Satellites show that recently it has been flowing more slowly and getting thicker, although it is still losing more ice than it gains. Observations from space are key to monitoring dynamic features such as this.

slides.caption: A stream of icebergs fills the Ilulissat Icefjord on 11 June 2019 (ESA)
Archived satellite images track the Jakobshavn Glacier’s calving front back to 1994.
Satellites also map elevation and thickness of the ice cap, and monitor its changes over time.
Ice velocity from multiple satellite radar observations, allowing scientists to understand long- and short-term dynamics.
